channel.title: Useful stuff if you want to start practicing Making Your Own Auto-Bot!
channel.description:
http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.3/docs/api/java/awt/Robot.html
i made a bot with this (simple but noob like) in 15 mins,
i made it always stay at north and always stay at same angle so it presses at right place using mousePress and mouseMove
and i used delay to make it more human like :)

item.title: Useful stuff if you want to start practicing Making Your Own Auto-Bot!
item.dc:creator: @Ben Ben
item.description:
@Ben wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:11, topic:2664”]Color GetColor(int x, int y)
{
return r.getPixelColor(x, y);
}

That Isnt Slow ?[/quote]

That actually will be slow, SCAR isn’t slow because it’s using the Windows API to get the pixels, with Robot you’ll have to take a screenshot or something, else you’ll have to scan by using Robot.getPixelColor(x,y), which is pretty slow.

Scanning with Robot.getPixelColor(x,y) means a for loop for x of about 500 loops, and another for loop for y of about 400 loops, which is 200k loops.

That might take some time, don’t you agree?

Read full topic
item.source: Useful stuff if you want to start practicing Making Your Own Auto-Bot!

item.title: Useful stuff if you want to start practicing Making Your Own Auto-Bot!
item.dc:creator: @Ben Ben
item.description:
@Ben wrote:

super is the super class, which means the class it extends.
Just like you can use this.myVar you can use super.myVar.

super just returns the super class – public class MyClass extends SuperClass

Read full topic

item.title: Useful stuff if you want to start practicing Making Your Own Auto-Bot!
item.dc:creator: @Ben Ben
item.description:
@Ben wrote:

public void moveMouse(int destX, int destY) {
	MouseEvent mouseEvent = new MouseEvent(c.aFrame_Sub1_17, 0, System.currentTimeMillis(), 0, destX, destY, 0, false);
	c.mouseMoved(mouseEvent);
}

public void clickMouse(int x, int y) {
	MouseEvent mouseEvent = new MouseEvent(c.aFrame_Sub1_17, 0, System.currentTimeMillis(), 0, x, y, 0, false);
	c.mousePressed(mouseEvent);
	mouseEvent = new MouseEvent(c.aFrame_Sub1_17, 0, System.currentTimeMillis(), 0, 0, 0, 0, false);
	c.mouseReleased(mouseEvent);
}

Replace c. with super. if you are putting these methods in client.java
(Using these methods will allow you to have the client minimized, and will basically do the same thing - generate a MouseEvent)

Read full topic

item.title: Useful stuff if you want to start practicing Making Your Own Auto-Bot!
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

guys, dont use this to make a bot :),

its a step in the right direction, experiment with the stuff and you will soon find more efficient ways of doing it ;)[br][size=1]Posted at: May 13, 2006, 12:09:32 pm[/size][hr][quote=“Iamadam, post:6, topic:2664”][quote author=Ollie link=topic=2929.msg28673#msg28673 date=1147480054]

Yeah i tried that but it isnt as good as good old SCAR
Awt.Robot was actually the first thing I did when I learned java - i thought it looked cool

thats why you create your own functions
[/quote]

Not much point in that when we have SCAR I made a ‘findColor’ function but it was soo slow.
Is good practice though :)[/quote]

Color GetColor(int x, int y)
{
return r.getPixelColor(x, y);
}

That Isnt Slow ?

Read full topic
